newsitem.title: USA: Silicon Graphics snaps up Russian virtual reality firm.
newsitem.headline: Silicon Graphics snaps up Russian virtual reality firm.

text.p: Russian Grand Master Garry Kasparov may have been beaten by a computer this week, but the world chess champion may get a payback on Wednesday if Silicon Graphics Inc. goes through with plans to acquire a computer company he helped found.
Sources close to the situation said Silicon Graphics is close to reaching an agreement to acquire privately held ParaGraph International Inc., with a decision possible as early as Tuesday night.

Founded in 1989 by Kasparov, Stepan Pachikov and a group of prominent Russian scientists, ParaGraph has become a leader in virtual reality and three-dimensional Web tools and software as well as pen-based technologies. Kasparov still holds a stake in ParaGraph, but the company declined to comment on the size of his holdings.

Kasparov became the first world chess champion to lose a match to a computer. Deep Blue, an International Business Machines supercomputer, defeated the Russian grandmaster over six games, winning two, drawing three and losing just once.
A Silicon Graphics spokesman declined comment on the potential acquisition.
ParaGraph executives were engaged in a conference call from their Campbell, Calif., headquarters and were not immediately available to comment, their office said.

Silicon Graphics has been active in the emerging world of creating three-dimensional environments on the Web and has bundled its Cosmo Player virtual reality browser with ParaGraph's Internet3D family of authoring tools.

Industry sources said the combination would be a logical step for Silicon Graphics, which has been a leader in the field of graphics and video production and animation as well as in Internet technology.
"The biggest issue is creating these cool 3D worlds and getting them delivered through the bandwidth constrained network," said one source familiar with Silicon Graphics' technology.

ParaGraph set out eight years ago to help people build their own worlds, and has since enabled the creation of 3-D Web sites inhabited with digital personalities known as avatars, along with co-authoring the Virtual Reality Modeling Language VRML standards.
The company's ink compression technology, known as Digital Ink, was originally developed for use in pen-based applications like Apple Computer Inc.'s Newton and Microsoft Corp.'s Windows CE.
Paragraph boosts an in-house team of 90 world class scientists, engineers and digital artists.

ParaGraph has projected its revenues will roughly double this year to $12 million. No price for the deal was immediately available, although one source said it will likeley be valued at less than $50 million.
The company has its headquarters in Campbell and maintains research and development facilities both there and in Moscow. ((sam.perry@reuters.com, Palo Alto Bureau 415 846 5400))
